docs.snippet: Courtroom dramas are a Hollywood staple. And what could be better than a drama pitting two powerful moguls against one another, two men who worked side by side for years to build an empire but now loathe each other. The drama -- better than most m...
docs.abstract: At the Movies column; real-life courtroom drama will be played out as Jeffrey Katzenberg demands about $250 million in bonuses he might have received as Disney studio chief; Michael Eisner, Disney head, says his former friend waived rights when he left job in 1994; public forum for acrimonious dispute is surprising in secretive world of studio executives; 28-year-old black filmmaker George Tillman Jr discusses his movie Soul Food; 84-year-old director Stanley Kramer, set to be honored by Directors Guild, comments on actors he has known; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Courtroom dramas are a Hollywood staple. And what could be better than a drama pitting two powerful moguls against one another, two men who worked side by side for years to build an empire but now loathe each other. The drama -- better than most movies -- is a real-life one, pitting Jeffrey Katzenberg against Michael Eisner. And to the amazement of virtually everyone in town -- including the two antagonists -- the issue is set to go before a Los Angeles Superior Court judge and jury on Nov. 18. On the face of it, the key issue is money -- Mr. Katzenberg (above) is seeking damages of about $250 million, insisting that his contract as studio chief at Disney for a decade rewarded him with bonuses based on profits of films and television produced during his tenure. Mr. Eisner's lawyers have responded that ''Katzenberg is simply not entitled to the enormous sums of money he now demands,'' largely because he waived his right to future bonuses when he left his job in 1994 instead of two years later.

headline.main: At the Movies; A Studio Drama In a Real Court

docs.snippet: Taste of Harlem     On Saturday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., soul, Caribbean, African and creole cuisines will be among those sampled, for a fee, at Taste of Harlem, part of Harlem Week. The food festival, which will be held on Lenox Terrace...
docs.lead_paragraph: Taste of Harlem On Saturday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., soul, Caribbean, African and creole cuisines will be among those sampled, for a fee, at Taste of Harlem, part of Harlem Week. The food festival, which will be held on Lenox Terrace Place, on West 135th Street between Fifth Avenue and Malcolm X Boulevard, will feature food from restaurants, bakeries and church kitchens. The Season of the Grouse Like Beaujolais nouveau from France, the first grouse of the shooting season are eagerly awaited each year in England. On Aug. 12, known as the glorious 12th, aristocrats dressed in tweeds and knickers and armed with 20-gauge shotguns wait in early morning Scottish Highland mists as drivers flush out the grouse. By mid-morning, the birds are on their way to top restaurants in London, destined for the dinner menu.

docs.snippet: MORE than 400 food festivals that will be held this year across the country are the subject of ''Food Festivals,'' a 428-page book by Barbara Carlson (Visible Ink, $14.95). Most of the gatherings, which are held annually, will take place from May ...
docs.abstract: More than 400 food festivals to be held across US in 1997 are subject of book, Food Festivals, written by Barbara Carlson; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: MORE than 400 food festivals that will be held this year across the country are the subject of ''Food Festivals,'' a 428-page book by Barbara Carlson (Visible Ink, $14.95). Most of the gatherings, which are held annually, will take place from May to October; many have regional themes. The festivals will feature everything from emu (in Texas) and bagels (in Illinois) to swamp cabbage (in Florida) and sorghum (in Tennessee and Georgia). Next month, there will be a shad festival in Windsor, Conn., and in September, the Okra Strut Festival will be held in Irmo, S.C., and a homage to bologna will take place in Lebanon, Pa. Four festivals will honor the pickle, and two will pay tribute to the prune. For information on the book, (800) 776-6265.

headline.main: Dish of Swamp Cabbage or Emu, Anyone?

docs.snippet: Prize Truffles    This is the peak season for white truffles from Italy. Retail prices this year are comparable to those of last season, $65 to $90 an ounce. And the quality is extremely good.    At a seven-course dinner featuring white truffles o...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prize Truffles This is the peak season for white truffles from Italy. Retail prices this year are comparable to those of last season, $65 to $90 an ounce. And the quality is extremely good. At a seven-course dinner featuring white truffles on Monday evening at San Domenico on Central Park South, a pound of truffles was auctioned off for $2,500. This prized collection consisted of four truffles, each about the size of a tangerine, that had been dug near Alba in the Piedmont region. The auction prize also included a 12-liter bottle of 1988 Ribezzo Barbera d'Alba.

docs.snippet: IN ''The Food and Life of Oaxaca'' (Macmillan, 1997, $32.50), Zarela Martinez, the owner of Zarela in Manhattan, describes in graceful language the history of this rugged region in southern Mexico. She tells of a culture that has been shaped and p...
docs.abstract: Amanda Hesser reviews The Food and Life of Oaxaca by Zarela Martinez, owner of Zarela restaurant in Manhattan; recipe for coloradito (reddish mole); photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IN ''The Food and Life of Oaxaca'' (Macmillan, 1997, $32.50), Zarela Martinez, the owner of Zarela in Manhattan, describes in graceful language the history of this rugged region in southern Mexico. She tells of a culture that has been shaped and preserved by an ancient people determined to resist the Spanish and anyone else who tried to influence them. The Oaxacans have also protected their cuisine, which is worlds away from Mexican food as most Americans know it. This is an ancient style of cooking, with mortar and pestle at the ready. It is rich and earthy, layered with chilies but not dominated by them. And though they have absorbed some Old World influences like cinnamon, cooking fats and a heavy use of meat, the core flavors remain indigenous ingredients like nuts, seeds, plantains and, of course, chilies.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: FOOD AND LIFE OF OAXACA, THE (BOOK)

docs.snippet: Fast Pasta and Sauce    Cucina Tosca, a line of pastas with sauce that take less than 10 minutes to prepare, is to be available in supermarkets in coming weeks. The products were developed by Pino Luongo, the restaurateur. "I wanted consumers to b...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fast Pasta and Sauce Cucina Tosca, a line of pastas with sauce that take less than 10 minutes to prepare, is to be available in supermarkets in coming weeks. The products were developed by Pino Luongo, the restaurateur. "I wanted consumers to be able to have a fresh-tasting sauce without preservatives," Mr. Luongo said. The hardest part, he said, was finding dried spaghetti that was short enough to fit in the box yet long enough to twirl around a fork at least four times. "You have to have four turns, otherwise an Italian would not be happy," he said.

docs.snippet: "HELLO, this is Arthur Schwartz," purred the newest voice in New York City talk radio. "You're on 'Food Talk.' "   Weekdays from 12:15 to 1 P.M. on WOR (710 on the AM dial), Mr. Schwartz, a cookbook writer and freelance restaurant critic, takes ca...
docs.lead_paragraph: "HELLO, this is Arthur Schwartz," purred the newest voice in New York City talk radio. "You're on 'Food Talk.' " Weekdays from 12:15 to 1 P.M. on WOR (710 on the AM dial), Mr. Schwartz, a cookbook writer and freelance restaurant critic, takes calls from anyone who wants to talk food. They usually end up discussing their love lives, work situations, weight problems and health concerns. Mr. Schwartz opens his heart when he opens his telephone lines.

headline.main: Talk Show Host (Subject, Food) Opens His Telephone Lines and His Heart

docs.snippet: Culinary Institute West    The Culinary Institute of America, one of the top professional cooking schools in the country, has announced that it will open a center for advanced studies in the Napa Valley in California. It plans to buy Greystone Cel...
docs.lead_paragraph: Culinary Institute West The Culinary Institute of America, one of the top professional cooking schools in the country, has announced that it will open a center for advanced studies in the Napa Valley in California. It plans to buy Greystone Cellars, a massive neo-Gothic building in St. Helena, from Heublein Inc.
